quote: That was an incredible program.
I am glad you approve. I have   always found the Black Sea at   night to be a most... stimulating   experience.

Worf, we were strolling barefoot   along the beach while balalaika   music played in the air... ocean   breeze washing over us... stars in   the sky... a full moon rising...   and the most you can say is   "stimulating"?
It was... very stimulating.
The truth is, I don't spend nearly   enough time on the Holodeck.
I should take my own advice and   use it to relax.       Next time, I'll choose the   program. If you like the Black   Sea, you're going to love Lake   Cataria on Betazed.
Deanna... perhaps before there is   a "next time" we should discuss...   Commander Riker.
Why, is he coming along?
No... but I do not wish to... I   mean, it would be unfortunate if   he... if you and I are going to   continue... I do not want to hurt   his feelings...
Worf... I think it's all right to   concentrate on our feelings...   yours... and mine.
Counselor!
What's today's date? The date?
Stardate 47988.
Captain, what's wrong?
I'm not sure... I don't know   how... or why, but...       I'm moving back and forth through   time.
It was as though I had physically   left the ship and gone to another   time and place... I was in the   past...
Can you describe where you were...   what it looked like?
It's all slipping away so fast...   like waking up from a nightmare...

It was years ago... before I took   command of the Enterprise. I was   talking with someone... I don't   remember who...       But then -- everything changed.   I wasn't in the past any longer...   I was an old man, in the future...   I was doing something outside...   what was it?
I'm sorry. It's gone. I can't   remember...
It's all right. Have you   considered the possibility that   this was just a dream?
It was more than a dream... the   smells and the sounds... the way   things felt to the touch... it was   all so real...
How long did you stay in each of   these time periods? Did it seem   like minutes... hours?

I'm not sure.       At first... there was a moment of   confusion, of disorientation. I   wasn't sure where I was. But that   passed... and then I felt   perfectly natural... as though I   belonged in that time. But I   can't remember how long I stayed   there.       I know this doesn't make much   sense... it's a feeling more than   a distinct memory.
Maybe we can identify specific   symbols. Can you remember   anything you saw, an object, a   building perhaps --
Captain Picard to the Bridge!
Sir, I think we have a problem   with the warp core, or the phase   inducers, or some other damn   thing.
Geordi...
Hello, Captain... or should I make   that Ambassador?
Hasn't been Ambassador for a while   either.
How about Mister Picard?
How about... Jean-Luc?
I don't know if I can get used to   that.
Good Lord, Geordi. How long has   it been?
Oh... about nine years.
No, no... I mean, since you last   called me Captain? When was the   last time we were all together...   on the Enterprise?
Close to twenty-five years.
Twenty-five years...       Time's been good to you.
It's been a little too good to me   in some places.
Can I give you a hand?
Oh... I'm just tying some vines.
Looks like you've got leaf miners.   Might want to use a bacillus   spray.       My wife is quite a gardener. I've   picked up a little bit of it.
How is Leah?
Busy as ever. She's just been   made director of the Daystrom   Institute.
And the little ones... Bret and   Alandra? And...
And Sidney. Not so little any   more. Bret's applying to   Starfleet Academy next year.
So what brings you here?
Oh... I just thought I'd drop by.   I'd been thinking about the old   days on the Enterprise... and I   was in the neighborhood...
Don't give me that. You don't   make the trip from Rigel Three to   Earth just to... drop by.
No.
So. You've heard.
Well... Leah has a few friends at   Starfleet medical... and word gets   around.
I'm not an invalid, you know.   Irumodic Syndrome can take years   to run its course.
I know. But when I heard I   just... wanted to come by all the   same.
Well... as long as you're here,   you can help me carry in some of   these tools.
My cooking may not be up to Leah's   standards, but I can still make a   decent cup of tea.
By the way, I read your last   novel. Not bad. I thought the   protagonist was written a bit   flamboyantly, but that's just my --
Captain, are you all right?   Captain?
Captain?
Are you all right, sir?
Sir... ?
I'm sorry, Lieutenant. My mind   seems to have wandered for a   moment...       What were you saying?
I was asking if you'd ever been   aboard a Galaxy Class starship   before, sir.
No. I'm, of course, very familiar   with the blueprints and   specifications... but this will   be my first time aboard.
Well then, sir, if I may be so   bold -- you're in for a treat.   The Enterprise is quite a ship.
I'm sure she is.
Have I done something wrong, sir?
No. You just seem very...   familiar.
Enterprise to Shuttlecraft   Galileo. You are cleared for   arrival in Shuttlebay Two.
Acknowledged, Enterprise.
There she is...
Captain?
Tasha... I was just with Tasha, in   the shuttle...
Troi to Doctor Crusher.   Something's wrong with the   Captain. We're on our way to   Sickbay.
I've finished the neurographic   scan. I don't see anything that   might cause hallucinations or a   psychogenic reaction.
Is there any indication of   temporal displacement?

No. Usually a temporal shift   would leave some kind of trypamine   residue in the cerebral cortex.   But the scan didn't find any.       Personally, I think you just enjoy   waking everyone up in the middle   of the night.
Actually, I just like running   around the ship in my bare feet.
The bio-spectral test results,   Doctor.
Your blood gas analysis is   consistent with someone who's been   breathing the ship's air for   weeks.
If you'd been somewhere else,   there would be some indication of   a change in your oxygen isotope   ratios.       Thanks, Alissa.
Deanna... would you excuse us?
Of course.
Jean-Luc... I scanned for any   evidence of Irumodic Syndrome, as   you suggested. There wasn't any.   But I did detect a small   structural defect in your parietal   lobe.
A defect... that you've never   noticed before?
It's the kind of thing that would   only show up on a level four   neurographic scan.       It could leave you susceptible to   several neurological disorders...   including Irumodic Syndrome.

Now, it's possible you could have   that defect for the rest of your   life without developing a   problem...       ... but even if you do... many   people lead perfectly normal lives   for a long time after the onset of   Irumodic Syndrome.
Then why do you look like you've   just signed my death sentence?
Sorry.       I guess... this has caught me off   guard.
Well, let's not worry about it.       Something tells me you're going to   have to put up with me for a very   long time.
It won't be easy, but I'll manage.
Did Worf find anything?
No, sir. His security scans came   up negative.
They're checking the sensor   logs... but there's still no   indication that you left the ship.
It wasn't a dream... something did   happen.
Worf to Captain.
Go ahead, Lieutenant.
Sir -- there is an incoming   transmission from Admiral   Nakamura. It is a priority one   message.
Beverly?
Mister Worf, route it through to   Doctor Crusher's office.
Captain.
Admiral.

I'm initiating a fleetwide Yellow   Alert. Starfleet intelligence has   picked up some disturbing reports   from the Romulan Empire. It   appears that at least thirty   Warbirds have been pulled from   other assignments and are heading   for the Neutral Zone.
Is there any indication why they   would make such a blatantly   aggressive move?

Our operatives on Romulus have   indicated that there appears to be   something happening in the Neutral   Zone -- specifically, in the   Devron System. Our own long range   scans have picked up some kind of   spatial anomaly in the area, but   we can't tell what it is.
What are our orders?

This is a delicate situation. I'm   deploying fifteen starships along   our side of the Neutral Zone. I   want you to go there as well --   see if you can find out what's   going on in the Devron System.
Am I authorized to enter the Zone?
Not yet. Wait and see what the   Romulans do. You can conduct long-range   scans, send probes if   necessary... but don't cross the   border unless they do.
Understood.
Captain... what's wrong?
This isn't my time. I belong   somewhere else...
What?
I mean... I... I wasn't here a   moment ago...
What do you mean? You've been   right here with me...
No, no... I was somewhere else...   a long time ago...       I was talking to someone...   Beverly... Beverly was there...
It's okay, Captain... everything's   going to be all right.
I'm not senile. It did happen.   I was here, with you... and then   I was in another place...       It was... it was back on the   Enterprise!
At least, I think it was... it   seemed like Sickbay... but maybe   it was a hospital... or...
Captain, I think we should go back   to the house... call a doctor...
No. I know what you're thinking.   It's the Irumodic Syndrome -- it's   beginning to -- to affect the old   man's mind. Well, it's not that.   And I wasn't daydreaming, either.
All right... all right... what do   you want do about it?
I want to see Data.
Data... Why?
I think he can help...
Help -- how?
I don't know! I don't know, but   I want to see him!
Okay... we'll go see Data. Is he   still at Cambridge?
Yes... yes... I think he's...
Do you see them?
See... who?
They're everywhere... laughing at   me... why are they laughing?
Come on, Captain... let's go see   Data.
Yes... Data... yes...
I know how it sounds... but it   happened. It was real. I was   back on the Enterprise.
How do you like your tea?
Tea? Earl Grey. Hot.
Of course it's hot. What do ya   want in it?
Nothing...
This is quite a place you have   here, Data. I see they treat   Professors pretty well at   Cambridge...
Holding the Lucasian Chair does   have its perquisites. This house   originally belonged to Sir Isaac   Newton when he held the position.   It has become the traditional   residence.
If you're really his friend,   you'll get him to take that grey   out of his hair. He looks like a   bloody skunk.
She can be trying at times.       But she does make me laugh.
What is it with your hair, anyway?
I have found that a touch of gray   adds an air of... distinction.
Is this Earl Grey? I'd swear it   was breakfast tea.
Captain, when was the last time   you saw a physician about your   Irumodic Syndrome?
A week ago. I was prescribed   peridaxon.
And yes, I know it's not a cure...   nothing can stop the deterioration   of my... my synaptic pathways...       You think I'm senile... that this   is all some... delusion.
No one said anything like that.
In all honesty, Captain, it's a   thought that has occurred to me.       However, there is nothing to   disprove what you are saying,   either. So it's possible   something is happening to you.

The first thing we should do is   give you a complete series of   neurographic scans. We can use   the equipment at the bio-metrics   lab here on campus.       Jessel, ask Professor Rippert to   take over my lecture for tomorrow   and possibly for the rest of the   week.
That's the Data I remember! I   knew I could count on you!
Commanding officer...   Enterprise... arriving.
To Captain Jean-Luc Picard,   Stardate 41148...
... You are hereby requested and   required to take command...
... to take command of the USS   Enterprise as of this date.   Signed Rear Admiral Norah Satie,   Starfleet Command.
Red Alert! All hands to Battle   Stations!
You heard him -- move!

Personal Log: Stardate 41153.7.   Recorded under security lockout   Omega three-two-seven. I have   decided not to inform this crew of   my experiences. If it's true that   I've travelled to the past, I   cannot risk giving them   foreknowledge of what's to come.
Report.
We've completed a full subspace   scan of the ship and surrounding   space. We detected no unusual   readings or anomalies.
With all due respect, sir... it   would help if we knew what we were   looking for.

Noted.       Counselor, do you sense anything   unusual aboard the Enterprise...   an alien presence that doesn't   belong here... perhaps operating   on a level of intelligence far   superior to our own?
No, sir. I'm only aware of the   crew... and the families aboard   the ship.
Mister Worf, I want you to   initiate a Level Two Security   Alert on all decks until further   notice.
Sir, with all due respect... I'm   the Security Chief on this ship.   Unless you're planning to make a   change...
No... no, of course not. Security   Alert Two, Lieutenant.
Aye, sir.
Captain Picard to the Bridge,   Please.
On my way, Chief.
Sir, Starfleet has just issued an   alert. It appears that a number   of vessels are moving toward the   Neutral Zone between Romulan and   Federation space.
What kind of vessels?
Freighters, transports... all   civilian. None of them Federation   ships.
It says a large spatial anomaly   has appeared in the Neutral   Zone...       In the Devron System.
Perhaps it is a Romulan trick --   to lure ships into the Neutral   Zone as an excuse for a military   strike.
Starfleet's cancelling our mission   to Farpoint Station and ordering   us to the Neutral Zone as soon as   we can leave spacedock.
No... no, we'll proceed to   Farpoint.
Sir?
You heard me.
But Captain -- the security of the   Federation may be at stake!
Man your station, Mister Worf.
Captain, perhaps if we understood   your thinking, if you could   explain --
I don't intend to explain   anything...       ... to anyone. We will proceed to   Farpoint Station, as originally   planned.
Now, if I'm not mistaken, Chief,   we're having some problems with   the warp plasma inducers.
That's right, sir.
I think I know a way to get them   back on-line. You're with me.       We'll be in Main Engineering.
I do not understand. The Romulans   may be planning an attack, and he   does not seem to care.       Are you certain this is the same   man who commanded the Stargazer?
As far as I know.
What are you going to do?
I'm going to do what I'm told....   prepare to go to Farpoint.
Mister O'Brien, use these   specifications to bypass the   secondary plasma inducer.
You have to realize, sir... this   isn't exactly my area of   expertise. The Chief Engineer   should be making these   modifications.
But the Chief Engineer isn't on   board yet.       Mister O'Brien... trust me. I   know you can do this.
All those years you spent as a   child... building model starship   engines... were well worth it.
How'd you know that, sir?
From... your Starfleet records.
Yes, sir. I'll get right to the   modifications.
Fletcher -- tell Munoz and Lee to   get up here right away. We have   to realign the entire power grid.   We're all going to be burning the   midnight oil on this one.
That would be inadvisable.
Excuse me?
If you attempt to ignite a   petroleum product on this ship at   zero-hundred hours -- it will   activate the fire suppression   system, which will seal off this   entire compartment.
Sir... that was just an   expression.
An expression of what?
A figure of speech... I was trying   to tell him that... we were going   to be working late...
Ah. Then "to burn the midnight   oil" implies late work?
That's right.
I am curious. What is the   etymology of that idiom? How did   it come to be used in contemporary   language?
I... don't know, sir...
Commander Data, welcome aboard --   it's good to see you.
It is... good to see you, too,   sir.
I could use your help with the   infusor array.
Certainly.
As you can see, we're having   difficulty with the plasma   conduits...
This will require a completely new   field induction subprocessor.       It appears that we will be   required to... ignite the midnight   petroleum, sir.
Jean-Luc... what's going on?
It happened again.
A time shift?
Yes...
What happened?
It's still a little vague, but I   can remember more this time. I   think the more I shift between   time periods, the more memory I   retain...
First, I was in what appeared to   be the future... years from now.   Then I was in the past again...   right before our first mission...
What is it?

I just scanned his temporal lobe   and compared it to the scan I   performed just a few minutes ago.   There's a thirteen percent   increase of acetylcholine in his   hippocampus.       Within a matter of minutes, you   accumulated over two days worth of   memories.
Counselor, do you remember the   first day I came aboard the   Enterprise?
Yes.
What happened after the welcoming   ceremony?
There was a reception in Ten   Forward... I introduced you to   Worf and the other senior   officers...
Do you have any memory of me   calling for a Red Alert in   spacedock? Do you remember   Starfleet diverting us from   Farpoint to the Neutral Zone to   investigate a spatial anomaly?
No...
It would appear that there is a   discontinuity between the time   periods you have described.   Events in one time period would   seem to have no effect on the   other two.
And yet in both the past and the   present -- there's a report of the   same anomaly in the Devron System.   It's hard to believe that's a   coincidence.
For all I know, there may be one   in the future, too.
Maybe the anomaly is some kind   of... temporal disruption.
But how is all this related to   your time shifting?

These are good questions. And I   suspect I might find some answers   when I return to the past... but   for now we're facing a potentially   dangerous threat from the   Romulans.       All departments should submit   combat readiness reports by oh   eight hundred hours tomorrow.   Dismissed.
Looks like it's going to be a late   night... want to get some dinner   first?
Actually, I...       I mean... we have plans.
Oh... I see. Well then... see you   tomorrow morning.
Goodnight, sir.
Worf...
... and I want continuous subspace   sweeps. We might detect a   temporal disturbance.
Aye sir.
Wil... this time shifting... when   it happens, I experience a moment   of disorientation. If this should   happen during a crisis, I want you   to be ready to take command   immediately.
Number One?
Sorry, Captain. Be prepared to   take command. Aye sir.
Speaking of disorientation... are   you all right?
Just a little distracted. I'm   fine.
You have the Bridge. I'll be in   my Ready Room.
Come.
Milk, warm -- dash of nutmeg.
What's this?
A prescription. A glass of warm   milk and eight hours uninterrupted   sleep.
Beverly...

Doctor's orders. You're   exhausted. I don't know if you've   slept in the past or the future...   but I know you haven't slept in   the present.       Get some rest, or I'll have you   relieved and sedated.
Yes, sir.
What's wrong?
Beverly.

As a physician, it's often my job   to give people unpleasant news...   to tell them that they need   surgery or that they can't have   children...       Or that they might be facing a   difficult illness...
You said yourself it's only a   possibility.
But you've been to the future...   you know it's going to happen.
I prefer to think of the future as   something that is not written in   stone. A lot of things can happen   in twenty-five years.
A lot of things can happen.
Sir? Wake up... sir?
Yes... yes, what is it? Have we   reached the Neutral Zone?
The Neutral Zone?
Sorry... I was... in the past   again...       What's going on?
Data's arranged for us to run some   tests on you in the bio-metrics   lab. We're ready to go if you   are.
No... no, we don't have time for   that. We have to get to the   Neutral Zone.
Why?
In the other two time periods...   Starfleet reported a... uh... some   kind of... spatial anomaly in   the... in the...       ... in the Devron System! The   Devron System in the Neutral Zone!
Sir...
If the anomaly was in the past...   it might be here, too. We have to   go find out...
Just because you've seen it in two   other time frames, doesn't mean   it's going to be here.
But if it is -- that means   something! Damnit, Geordi -- I   know what we have to do!
Okay... but first of all, there is   no Neutral Zone, remember?
Right... right. Klingons... in   this time period, the Klingons   have taken over the Romulan   Empire...
And the relations between us and   the Klingons aren't real cozy   right now.
I know that. I haven't completely   lost my mind, you know.
Sorry, Geordi... it's hard for me   to concentrate... and remember   things... I don't mean to take   out that frustration on you...
It's okay...       Well, if we're going to the Devron   System, we're going to need a   ship.
I think it's time to call in some   old favors...       Contact Admiral Riker at Starbase   Two-four-seven.
Jean-Luc, you know I'd like to   help... but frankly, what you're   asking for is impossible. The   Klingons have closed their borders   to all Federation starships.
Wil... if this... spatial anomaly   really is in the Devron System...
I saw a report from Starfleet   Intelligence on that sector this   morning. There's no activity...   there's nothing unusual happening   in the Devron System.
I don't believe that! Maybe their   long-range scanners are flawed...   we have to go there, see for   ourselves!
Data, what do you make of all   this?
I am not certain. I cannot   disprove what the Captain is   saying.       And he is convinced he is   travelling back and forth through   time.
Right.       Look, I've got the Yorktown out   near the border... I'll have them   run some long range scans of the   Devron System... if they find   anything, I'll let you know.
That's not good enough.
It's going to have to be. I'm   sorry. That's all I can do.   Riker out.
Computer -- restore holographic   image.
Damn him anyway... after all we've   been through together... he's been   sitting behind that desk too long.
Well... I guess all we can do is   wait to see if the Yorktown finds   anything.
There is another option.
We could arrange passage aboard a   medical ship.
Medical ship?
Yes. There was an outbreak of   Terrellian Plague on Romulus. The   Klingons have been allowing   Federation medical ships to cross   the border.
Yes... yes...
So now all we need is a medical   ship.
I think I can arrange that.       Find the USS Pasteur. I have some   pull with the Captain.       At least, I used to...
Well... this is a page out of the   past. I never thought I'd see any   one of you on a starship again.       Data, Geordi...
Let's just... choose one.
Well. Did you get my message?
Yes. Jean-Luc... going into   Klingon territory -- it's insane.       But I never could say no to you.
Ah. So that's why you married me.
Now... the first order of business   is to get clearance to cross the   Klingon border.
What about Worf? Isn't he still   on the Klingon High Council?
I'm not sure. Information on the   Klingon political structure is   hard to come by these days.   However, at last report Worf was   governor of H'atoria, a small   Klingon colony near the border.
Worf... yes, that's it... that's   the answer. Worf. He'll help us.   Let's make it so.
Captain Picard?
Yes?
Yes?
Captain, McKinley Station is   signalling. They want to know   when we'll be docking.
Tell McKinley that we've been   called away on a priority mission.   We won't be docking.
Aye, sir.
Kept the name, eh?
I've prepared quarters for you on   Deck Five if you'd like some rest.
I'm fine. I don't need any rest.
Nell, please escort the Ambassador   to his quarters--
I can find my way around a   starship!
You're all treating me like an   invalid, but I assure you I've got   a few years left. I don't need to   be led around and I don't want to   be patronized.
You're right. I'm sorry.
I'll go have a rest.
How long since he's had a   neurological scan?
I'm not sure, but don't waste your   time suggesting it. He says he's   not taking "any more damn tests."
Do you believe he's moving through   time?
I don't know if I do, either...   but -- he's Jean-Luc Picard. And   if he wants to go on one more   mission, that's what we're going   to do.
Ensign Chilton, set course for   H'atoria.
We'll find the anomaly... I know   we will...
Report.
We're nearing the coordinates you   gave me, sir.
Is there anything unusual in the   vicinity?
How would you define unusual, sir?   Every region of space has unique   properties that cannot be found   anywhere else.
There should be a... "barrier" of   some sort nearby. A large plasma   field... highly disruptive.
Nothing, sir.
It's the right time... right   place... he should be here...
Who, sir?
Q! We're here! This has gone on   long enough! What sort of game   are you playing?
Counselor, do you sense an alien   presence?
No, sir.
What is a... "Q"?
It's a letter of the alphabet, as   far as I know.
This is not the way it's supposed   to happen...       Maintain position here. I'll be   in my Ready Room.
Mon Capitan... I thought you'd   never get here.
Q... I thought so. What's going   on?
It's Judge Q to you. And isn't it   obvious what's going on?
The last time I stood in this   courtroom was seven years ago...
"Seven years ago... " How little   you mortals understand time. Must   you be so linear, Jean-Luc?
You accused me of being the   representative of a barbarous   species...
I believe my exact words were "a   dangerous, savage, child-race."
But we demonstrated that mankind   has become peaceful and   benevolent. You agreed, and let   us go on our way.       Why do I find myself back in this   courtroom?
You'd like me to connect the dots   for you. Lead you from A... to   B... to C... so your puny mind   can comprehend.
How boring. They would be so much   more entertained if you tried to   figure this out...
I'll answer any ten questions that   call for a "yes" or a "no."       Well?
Are you putting mankind on trial   again?
No.
Is there any connection at all   between the trial seven years   ago... and whatever's going on   now?
Hmmmmm... I would have to say...   yes.
The spatial anomaly in the Neutral   Zone -- is it related to what's   happening?
Oh, most definitely yes.
Is it part of a Romulan plot? A   ploy to start a war?
No... and no. Five down.
That's only four --
"Is it a Romulan plot?" "Is it a   ploy to start a war?" Those are   separate questions.
Did you create the anomaly?
No, no, no. You're going to be so   surprised when you realize where   it came from -- if you ever figure   it out.
Are you responsible for my   shifting through time?
I'll answer that if you promise   you won't tell anyone.       Yes.
Why?
Oh, I'm sorry. That's not a "yes   or no" question. You forfeit the   rest of your questions.
I expected as much. You're such   a limited creature... a perfect   example of why we've made our   decision.
The trial never ended, Captain.   We never reached a verdict. But,   now we have: you're guilty.
Guilty of what?
Of being inferior.
Seven years ago I said we'd be   watching you. And we have been.   Hoping your ape-like race would   demonstrate some growth... give   some indication that your minds   have room for expansion.

And what have we seen instead?   You spending time worrying about   Commander Riker's career...   listening to Counselor Troi's   pedantic psychobabble...   indulging Data in his witless   exploration of humanity...
We have journeyed to countless new   worlds... made contact with new   species... expanded man's   understanding of the universe...
In your own paltry, limited way.   You have no idea how far you still   have to go.
We are what we are, Q -- and we're   doing the best we can. It's not   for you to set the standard by   which we're judged.
Oh, but it is. And we have. Time   may be eternal -- but our patience   is not.
Having rendered a verdict... have   you decided upon a sentence?
Indeed. It's time to put an end   to your trek through the stars...   to make room for other, more   worthy species.
We're to be denied travel through   space?
Q... even you could not be capable   of such an act --
I? There you go again, blaming me   for everything. Well, this time   I'm not your enemy. I am not the   one who causes the annihilation of   mankind.       You are.
Me...
That's right. You're doing it   right now... you've already done   it... and you will do it yet   again.
What sort of meaningless doubletalk   is that?

He doesn't understand. I have   only myself to blame, I suppose.   I believed in you... I thought you   had potential... but apparently I   was wrong.       May whatever God you believe in   have mercy on your soul. This   court stands adjourned.
Commander, assemble the Senior   Staff and go to Red Alert.       We have a bigger problem than we   thought.

If I weren't traveling through   time... I would never have   realized that the anomaly in the   Neutral Zone appeared there in the   past as well.       Assuming that's an important piece   of a larger puzzle, my ability to   shift through time may be the key   to understanding what's going on.

Still nothing, Captain. I've   conducted a full sensor sweep out   to one light year from the   Pasteur. No temporal anomalies,   no particle fluctuations...   nothing.

Yes. The subspace barrier is a   little thin in this region of   space, but that's not unusual.

The rupture may be sending out   waves of temporal energy which are   disrupting the normal flow of   time.

Oh, my god.

Leave me alone! I'm not crazy.   The tachyon pulses... they -- they   were used in the same spot -- in   all three time periods... don't   you see? Sir... can you give us some   explanation?
No. I cannot.

Captain, so far we've obeyed every   order -- no matter how far-fetched   it might have seemed. But if   we're to risk the safety of the   ship and crew... I think we have   to ask you for an explanation.

I know all of you have doubts   about me... about each other...   about the ship. All I can say is   that even though we've only been   together for a short time... I   know that you are the finest crew   in the fleet... and I would trust   each of you with my life.       I'm asking you to make a leap of   faith -- and trust me.
Shields up, maximum strength.
Boosting field integrity on the   warp nacelles. We may encounter   shearing forces once we enter the   anomaly.
I am preparing to initiate a   static warp shell.
Course laid in, sir.
All decks report ready, Captain.
Chief... take us in.
Captain, I have an idea. If we   take the ship to the center of the   anomaly and create a static warp   shell...
... a static warp shell, it could   repair the barrier and collapse   the anomaly.
Yes, sir.
Mister Data, you're a clever man --   in any time period.
Lay in a course to the center of   the anomaly. Prepare to initiate   a static warp shell.
The other two Enterprises...   they're on their way.
Very well.       Ensign... take us in.
We're entering the anomaly, sir.
All hands brace for impact!
The temporal energy's interfering   with main power. Switching to...
... auxiliary power. I'm having   trouble keeping the impulse   engines on-line! I've got power   fluctuations all across the board!
Maintain course and speed!       Mister Data, how long until we   reach the center?
Another thirty seconds at least,   Captain.
We've entered the anomaly.
We have reached the center, sir.
Initiate warp shell!
Initiating static warp shell --   now.
Is it having any effect?
Something is happening... A new   subspace barrier appears to be   forming --
Captain! Sensors are picking   up... two other ships...
Captain, It appears to be working.   The anomaly is beginning to   collapse. I think that --
Sir -- the temporal energy is   rupturing our warp containment   system!
We must eject the core!
No. We have to maintain the   static warp shell for as long as   possible!
We're losing containment! I can't   stop it, it's going to --
Transfer emergency power to the   anti-matter containment system!
I'm trying, sir... but there's a   lot of interference...
The warp shell is definitely   having an effect, sir. The   anomaly is collapsing --
The containment system's going --   I can't hold it --
Maintain position! Mister La   Forge --
Both of the other ships have been   destroyed.
Two down... one to go.
Data, report!
The anomaly is nearly collapsed...
We're losing containment...
Goodbye, Jean-Luc. I'll miss you.   You did have so much potential.   But I guess... all good things   must come to an end.
Containment field at critical!   I'm losing it --
The Continuum didn't think you had   it in you, Jean-Luc... but I knew   you could.
Are you saying it worked? We   collapsed the anomaly?
Is that all this meant to you?   Just another spatial anomaly...   just another day at the office?
Q, did it work?
You're here, aren't you? You're   talking to me, aren't you?
What about my crew?
"The anomaly... my crew... my   ship." I suppose you're worried   about your fish too. Well, if it   puts your mind at ease, you've   saved humanity once again.
Thank you.
For what?
You had a hand in helping me get   out of this.
I was the one who got you into it,   Jean-Luc. That was the directive   from the Continuum.       The part about the helping hand...   was my idea.
I sincerely hope this is the last   time I'll find myself here.
You just don't get it, do you,   Jean-Luc?       The trial never ends.
We wanted to see if you had the   ability to expand your mind and   your horizons... and for one brief   moment, you did.
When I realized the paradox...

Exactly. For that one fraction of   a second, you were open to options   you'd never considered. That's   the exploration that awaits you...   not mapping stars and studying   nebulae... but charting the   unknowable possibilities of   existence.
What are you trying to tell me, Q?
You'll find out.       In any case, I'll be watching...   and if you're lucky, I'll drop by   to say hello from time to time.       See you out there.
Captain, are you all right?
Worf... what's the date?
Stardate 47988.
Is something wrong, sir?
No, no... in fact, I think I'll go   back to bed. I could use some   sleep.

Captain's Log, supplemental.   Starfleet Command reports no   unusual activity along the Neutral   Zone, and there is no sign of a   temporal anomaly. It would appear   that I am the only member of the   crew to retain any knowledge of   the events I experienced.
That's it for me.
There's always next time.
That's four hands in a row. How   does he do it?
I cheat.
I'm kidding.
I've been thinking... about all   the things the Captain told us   about the future. The way we   changed and drifted apart... why   would he tell us what's to come?
It sure goes against everything   we've heard about not polluting   the time line...
I believe, however, that this   situation is unique.

Since the temporal anomaly did not   occur, there have already been   changes in the way this time line   is unfolding. The future we   experience will undoubtedly be   different from the one the Captain   encountered.
Maybe that's why he told us.   Knowing what that future could   bring... gives us a chance to   change things now.
So that some things never happen.
Come in.
Am I too late?
Not at all. Have a seat.

No. I just thought I might...   join you this evening. If there's   room...

Oh... thank you.
